presentation.title: The Three Pillars of API Governance
presentation.toc: API Governance becomes increasingly challenging with increasing organizational size: How to best balance the needs of faster ways of developing products with the needs of an organization that has to manage many of these products? Pillar #1 of API Governance are insights: In order to understand where the API landscape is moving, it is important to understand what it looks like. Pillar #2 of API Governance are interfaces: APIs are saying that how things are built is of no concern to a capability's user, but that what is being built can make a big difference in terms of how APIs are discovered and used. Pillar #3 of API Governance is nudging: The most effective way to evolve API landscapes is when teams make all the right design and implementation decisions by themselves. Using these three pillars of API governance, enterprise architects and platform teams can have a substantial and productive influence on an organization's API landscape.

part.title: From Building Systems to Designing Ecosystems

ul.li: You know what products teams are delivering but not how they are producing them
There can be no hidden dependencies between products
Delivery velocity increases because teams can pick tools and can move at their own speed
Consumers satisfaction increases because products get released and changed more quickly
Minimizing constraints maximizes team autonomy and thus productivity
Coherence across products must be managed
Identifying and supporting cross-product concerns increases landscape productivity
Building openness and robustness into the landscape is critical
APIs can be described in a variety of ways
Technical descriptions for interface mechanics (e.g., OpenAPI and AsyncAPI)
Documentation intended for human consumption
Metadata helping with API lifecycle management (e.g., APIs.json and schema.org)
API description requirements
Be independent of API technology and implementation
Define an evolving set of well-known elements
Provide openness for custom additions
Support existing formats for backwards-compatibility
Build on existing patterns and specifications for description on the Web
Aim for the minimal number of constraints for your API landscape
Minimizing constraints maximizes the freedom of teams
Revisit existing constraints and remove/relax them when possible
Look at rules at suggestions how to satisfy constraints
Help teams to satisfy constraints if they want/need help
Try to make rules optional whenever possible
Teams communicate through their API dependencies
Avoid hidden dependencies like shared libraries
There are no shortcuts: APIs are the only way to create dependencies
API stories help with the design of product APIs
Implementation details and concerns are never made visible
Implementation changes can be done safely
More API teams mean more ways to solve the same problem
Solving API problems is not what teams should focus on
Solving API problems in a consistent way helps the API landscape
Communications across teams is a challenge
Complement channels with documentation of practices

slide.title: The Anatomy of a Good Guideline

ul.li: Why does the guideline exist?
Rationale for creating the guideline
What can be done to address the described issue
At least one good solution for addressing the issue
How to implement the solution
At least one way to use the solution in practice
Testing that the guideline has been followed
Some tests can be automated but many will be by declaration or review
Solutions (What) are addressing design challenges
Have a model for accepting new solutions
Practices (How) are implementing a solution
Have a model for accepting new practices
Guidelines should be managed in a participatory way
Guidelines are for capturing and sharing experiences across API teams
Everybody can comment or contribute to the guidelines
Over time it may make sense to develop a more formal approval process
There may be editors but their role is to improve guideline quality
Tooling should reflect the nature as a living document
One-way tooling is a bad choice
Collaborative tooling is a good choice
Start capturing feedback from API teams
Challenges along the way
Solutions they have found or implemented
Quantifying the time they spend with cross-cutting vs. domain tasks
Start editing and providing guidance that API teams can find and use
Tooling can be as simple as markdown and shared repositories
Treat your API Guidelines as a product
There are well-defined user stories as well as goals and non-goals
There is clear ownership of the product (which is different from the content)
Good guidelines result in better APIs and more effective API teams
